G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court under G.L. c. 223, §2 because the rental property and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred within this judicial district.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3, and G.L. c. 218, §19.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3, and G.L. c. 218, §19.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes a statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, §14.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord liable for failing to curb nightclub noise adversely affecting tenants' quiet enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that landlords breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructively evicted residential tenants by failing to control excessive noise from a bar/cocktail lounge operated on premises they leased to others. The court emphasizes that because the landlords created the situation, had the right and ability to control the lounge’s noise, and the disturbance was a natural and probable consequence of their leasing arrangement, they were liable and could not collect rent. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord is liable for failing to curb nightclub noise that interferes with tenants’ quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “The judge further found that…the landlords ‘had it within their control to correct the conditions which… amounted to a constructive eviction of each [tenant].’… The landlords introduced a commercial activity into an area where they leased premises for residential purposes. The lease for the lounge expressly provided that entertainment in the lounge had to be conducted so that it could not be heard outside the building and would not disturb the residents of the leased apartments… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al Zabin v. Picucci, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Al Zabin v. Picucci, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 198 (1983)
Al Zabin v. Picucci, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Al Zabin v. Picucci, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 198 (1983) (landlord’s failure to act against tenants causing disturbances constituted interference).
Al Zabin v. Picucci, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about murder, armed robbery, felony‑murder instructions, joint enterprise, evidentiary rulings, and joinder. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, interference, or any discussion of a landlord’s failure to act against disturbing tenants. The proposition concerns landlord liability for interference, which is unrelated to the legal and factual issues in this decision, so the citation does not support the stated proposition.
Al Zabin v. Picucci, 17 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt:
We discern no abuse of discretion in the judge’s denying severance of the charges. See Sylvester, supra at 754; Commonwealth v. Jervis, 368 Mass. 638, 645 (1975); Commonwealth v. Gallison, 383 Mass. 659, 671-672 (1981). He did take the precaution of severing the defendant’s trial from Kirkland’s.

Judgments affirmed.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (constructive interference with quiet enjoyment found where disturbances persisted after notice).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion finds a breach of quiet enjoyment based on failure to furnish heat, but it does not discuss notice by the tenant or the persistence of disturbances after such notice. The court focuses on the objective consequences of the landlord’s conduct and rejects financial inability as a defense; it does not frame the violation in terms of ‘constructive interference’ persisting after notice. Thus the case supports liability for failure to provide heat under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but not the specific notice-related proposition stated.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr. v.raw_text: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr. v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018)
Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr. v.proposition: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr. v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (quiet enjoyment includes protection from unreasonable disturbances).

Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.raw_text: Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985)
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.proposition: Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985) (tenant entitled to relief where landlord failed to address conditions interfering with sleep).
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.support_reasoning: The opinion supports tenant relief for serious habitability defects and emotional distress, but it does not discuss conditions specifically interfering with sleep (e.g., noise, light, or similar disturbances). The court’s focus is on soot from a defective furnace, violations of the State Sanitary Code, warranty of habitability, covenant of quiet enjoyment, and G.L. c. 93A, not on sleep-related interference as such. Thus, using this case for the narrower proposition about conditions interfering with sleep overstates what the decision actually holds.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.relevant_excerpt: 1. The defendants were seriously at fault in failing to bring the plaintiffs’ apartment into habitable condition and to keep it so. Most grievous among the defects was the lamentable condition of the oil fired furnace and connected heating apparatus, which was supposed to deliver clean heat to the apartment, but in fact corrupted it and all within it with clinging soot. … 3. Also allowed was a total of $2,000 for emotional distress. This injury was found to be a consequence of the defendants’ wrongful acts and omissions in maintaining the apartment, see G. L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (quiet enjoyment breach includes substantial interference causing mental distress).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 allows recovery of emotional distress damages where the landlord’s reckless conduct causes substantial interference. It explains that “actual and consequential” damages under the quiet enjoyment statute include personal injuries such as emotional harm, and in discussing overlapping damages it explicitly treats emotional distress as a compensable consequence of the interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case supports the proposition that a quiet enjoyment breach can include substantial interference resulting in mental distress.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. … Generally, ‘actual damages’ are losses flowing directly from a wrongful act. … ‘Consequential damages’ cover all losses that are reasonably foreseeable to the actor… For example, consequential damages in an action based on contract or warranty may include personal injuries caused by the breach. … The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”

Yee v. New England College of Optometry,.raw_text: Yee v. New England College of Optometry, 438 Mass. 102 (2002)
Yee v. New England College of Optometry,.proposition: Yee v. New England College of Optometry, 438 Mass. 102 (2002) (covenant breached by acts or omissions materially impairing use).
Yee v. New England College of Optometry,.case_name: Sheriff of Suffolk County v. Pires
Yee v. New England College of Optometry,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Yee v. New England College of Optometry (actually a habeas/bail case involving Pires) deals exclusively with whether a writ of habeas corpus is a proper vehicle to challenge a bail revocation order under G.L. c. 276, § 58. It does not involve covenants, contracts, or the standard for when a covenant is breached, nor does it discuss acts or omissions materially impairing use. The proposition about breach of covenant is therefore unrelated to the legal issues and holding in this case, so the citation does not support it.
Yee v. New England College of Optometry,.relevant_excerpt: “In answer to the question reserved and reported by the single justice, a petition for a writ of habeas corpus is not generally the proper means by which to appeal from a bail revocation order. The writ issued by the Superior Court was therefore issued in error.”

Snyder v. Collura, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 112.raw_text: Snyder v. Collura, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 1124 (2012)
Snyder v. Collura, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 112.proposition: Snyder v. Collura, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 1124 (2012) (summary decision confirming landlord liability for failure to ameliorate known noise).

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (recognizing tenant’s right to habitable, undisturbed premises).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This separate opinion explicitly endorses abandoning caveat emptor in residential leases, recognizing that a landlord renting a dwelling unit impliedly agrees to provide premises that meet statutory minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, and that the tenant’s rent obligation is mutually interdependent with that duty. While Justice Quirico dissents from the majority’s broader formulation of an implied warranty of habitability, he clearly recognizes a tenant’s right to habitable premises and to be free from substantial violations of the sanitary code; the undisturbed-possession aspect is implicit in making habitability a landlord obligation tied to rent. Because this is a concurrence/dissent rather than the majority, it only moderately supports the proposition but is directionally accurate.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.

Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180 (1990)
Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.proposition: Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. App. Ct. 180 (1990) (landlord responsible for ensuring peaceful possession under lease).
Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an attorney’s fee-shifting provision in a contract for services and whether a contingent fee agreement had to be disclosed to an arbitrator, analyzed under Rule 60(b) and Massachusetts arbitration law. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, leases, or any discussion of a landlord’s obligation to ensure a tenant’s peaceful possession. Thus, citing this case for the proposition that a landlord is responsible for ensuring peaceful possession under a lease is inaccurate and unsupported by the decision.
Winthrop Corp. v. Lowenthal, 29 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: "Here, the source of the award of legal fees is the provision in the contract between Winthrop and Lowenthal stating that the prevailing party in any action or proceeding ‘shall be entitled to recover its costs and reasonable attorney’s fees’ (emphasis added). In order to consider whether Mr. Singer’s conduct constituted fraud on the court, we first determine if he was required to disclose the existence of the contingent fee agreement."
